column1: Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) is an enzyme in the body.
This article discusses the test to measure the amount of CPK in the blood.
This test may be repeated over 2 or 3 days if you are a patient in the hospital.

This test may be used to: - Diagnose heart attack - Evaluate cause of chest pain - Determine if or how badly a muscle is damaged - Detect dermatomyositis, polymyositis, and other muscle diseases - Tell the difference between malignant hyperthermia and postoperative infection The pattern and timing of a rise or fall in CPK levels can be significant in making a diagnosis.

High CPK levels may be seen in people who have: - Brain injury or stroke - Convulsions - Delirium tremens - Dermatomyositis or polymyositis - Electric shock - Heart attack - Inflammation of the heart muscle (myocarditis) - Lung tissue death (pulmonary infarction) - Muscular dystrophies - Myopathy - Rhabdomyolysis Other conditions that may give positive test results include: - Hypothyroidism - Hyperthyroidism - Pericarditis following a heart attack
